text: Moschion, (), a physician quoted by Soranus,ap. Galen, De Compos. Medicam. sec. Loc., i. 2, vol. xii. Andromachus,ap. Galen, De Compos. Medicam. sec. Loc., vii. 2, vol. xiii. and Asclepiades Pharmacion,ap. Galen, De Compos. Medicam. sec. Gen., iii. 9, vol. xiii. and who lived, therefore, in or before the 1st century. He may be the same person who was called the Corrector (), because though he was one of the followers of Asclepiades of Bithynia, he ventured to controvert his opinions on some points.Galen, De Differ. Puls., iv. 16, vol. viii. A physician of the same name is mentioned also by Soranus,Soranus, De Arte Obstetr. Plutarch,Plutarch, Sympos., iii. 10.2 Alexander of Tralles,Alexander of Tralles, i. 15 AëtiusAëtius, iv. 3.13 Pliny,Pliny, H. N., xix. 26.4 and Tertullian.Tertullian, De Anima, c. 15 In Byzantine times, a Latin treatise on gynecology by an otherwise unknown Muscio was translated into Greek; this author came to be wrongly identified with Moschion.Owsei Temkin, (1991), Soranus' Gynecology, page xlv.
